name: Mark Takano
tweet_text: He passed away in Massa, Italy, just a few short weeks before WWII came to an end. My great uncle Monso never got to see the fruits of his service, but he would be proud to know that he won his bet for America and that we turned a page on that dark time in our history.

name: Mark Takano
tweet_text: As we take an opportunity to remember the loved ones we lost on the battlefield, I reflect on the story of my great uncle Monso. He was a young, 23-year-old Japanese American who fought for his country, even as his relatives were imprisoned in internment camps at home.

name: Mark Takano
tweet_text: I strongly oppose this new dangerous practice — everyone should — as it subverts the basic notions of freedom, autonomy, and presumed innocence. We cannot allow the Trump Administration to continue carrying out their anti-immigrant agenda & undermining our American values. (6/6)

name: Mark Takano
tweet_text:
Immigrants are already required to give out a lot of personal identifying information to immigration officials. Forcing them to give up DNA data jeopardizes their civil and privacy rights.

No one deserves this type of government surveillance and unjust criminalization. (5/6)

name: Mark Takano
tweet_text: This type of DNA data collection is completely unjustified and can have harmful and long-lasting consequences. It could lead to the start of a de facto national DNA database full of DNA data from all individuals who live or traverse in the U.S. — including U.S. citizens. (4/6)

name: Mark Takano
tweet_text:
DHS also claims that DNA collection will identify “fraudulent” family units at the border. This is problematic.

-DHS' own data disproves this claim
-DHS hasn’t clarified how a child traveling w/ a relative other than a parent, like an aunt/cousin/grandparent, is classified (3/6)

name: Mark Takano
tweet_text:
DHS is attempting to justify these DNA collection practices by characterizing immigrants in detention as “potential criminals.” 

This blatantly xenophobic practice aims to miscast immigrants as inherently dangerous. We know that immigrants are less likely to commit crimes. (2/6)

name: Mark Takano
tweet_text:
The Trump Administration is starting to collect the DNA of detainees at the border, including children, and uploading these DNA profiles to an FBI criminal database.
 
This is invasive and unjustified.

Here's why everyone should be very concerned. (1/6) https://t.co/HRVF38830m

tweet_text:
The trade secrets privileges of software developers should never trump the due process rights of defendants. As technological innovations enter our criminal justice system, we need to ensure that our rights are protected.

Read more about my bill here: https://t.co/4wtkYwml1D

name: Mark Takano
tweet_text:
To address this injustice, I introduced the Justice in Forensic Algorithms Act.

This bill ensures that defendants can access source code to challenge evidence used against them. It also sets standards and testing to assess whether forensic algorithms are fair enough to be used. https://t.co/nkkDCi577Y

name: Mark Takano
tweet_text: People are being convicted based on evidence analyzed by potentially flawed forensic algorithms. But they can't challenge this evidence due to the intellectual property rights of software developers. This is unjust and directly undermines a defendant’s due process rights.
